text: hi everyone Anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new stormzy
record this is what I mean this is a
brand new LP from rapper songwriter and
singer stormzy one of the most
commercially successful and culturally
defining hip-hop artists who come out of
the UK he even dropped one of my
favorite records of 2019 heavy is the
head which was loaded with thoughtful
bangers tasteful pop crossovers
ambitious production and a lot of heart
as well and this mix of Vibes this
versatility among other things is what
makes stormzy so compelling so I can't
say I'm entirely surprised by the
direction of this new album leaning
pretty heavily into some pianos and
stormzy singing voice again not
surprised because on numerous tracks in
the past the stormzy has revealed
himself to be a pretty vulnerable guy
the straight up hip-hop cuts on this
record are kind of more the exception
than the rule which is not necessarily a
bad thing as long as what it's being
swapped out for is done well and doesn't
and expose some kind of shortcoming I
guess but that's kind of the problem
with this is what I mean it does it does
expose a shortcoming though I do think
this record starts off very strong and
comes from a very personal and emotional
place for stormzy the rich Melancholy
and gospel inspired chords Through the
first leg of fire and water are gorgeous
and match well with stormzy's very weary
and understated lead vocals from here
there's a lot of froggy bars to follow
about heartbreak and regret the track
continues to roll out some great changes
across its eight minute run time like
the exhilarating beat drop in the second
act as well as the luxurious grooves
horns and expressive background vocals
in the last leg which help us move from
the metaphorical fire in the first leg
of the song to The sought after water in
its final moments a progression that is
mirrored in the overall album's run time
as well from here there's the track this
is what I mean which is easily the
biggest Bop on this LP with a tight trap
beat epic Coral hits so some grimy bass
and it's great but it's also kind of a
shame that this is one of the most
thrilling moments on the entire LP and
it's happening so early the fact that
this is the hardest the record goes
feels like uh doing a song in this vein
is almost like I don't know an
obligation of some sort like the whole
thing can't be a snooze Fest we got to
have one track in here that's kind of
slick switching off to fire babe which
is genuinely one of the most moving love
songs I've heard this year the records
thematic ties between fire and passion
return in a big way on this track too
with some gorgeous electric piano chords
and A tear-jerker Chorus for sure this
track is going to be someone's wedding
song in 2023 not just because of the
sentiment of it but there's a beautiful
Stillness to it that uh is is like that
of what goes on in your mind when you
see someone who's kind of beautifully
mind-blowing but from here I think the
track list on this LP starts to take a
nosedive and exposes a lack of
development as well as textural flavor
for as good and as heartfelt as some of
the sentiments on please are for example
especially when stormzy is rapping about
forgiving his father the way the track
ends off and just kind of flows into
this whole Coral section makes it feel a
little inconclusive like another verse
could have easily been here the track
feels more like an internal monologue or
a very quiet prayer than a formal song
it's also a bit of a jarring switch up
going into the very buttery smooth
grooves of need you the tracks faux
sensuality is propped up with stuttering
bits of bass some elevator Jazz horns as
well as a very dulled up breathy guest
vocals that are not eliciting The Vibes
they think they are neither is stormzy's
very quiet vocal fry on his verses it
kind of sounds like a sexy ASMR or at
least an attempt at that the Romantic
Vibes continue on to the track hide and
seek which I'm not against a romantic
cut in theory I just hate that stormzy
and his producers in an attempt at doing
something with a romantic sentiment trip
into some of the most cliche pitfalls
that you'll find with nearly any track
going for this Vibe it's like the super
sappy chorus and the overabundance of
Reverb as well as a beat that is so
polite it's just trying not to make an
impression I'll have to get
grandfathered into this equation because
we've heard so many tracks in the past
just like it the record doesn't really
pick up again in my opinion until my
presidents are black which is an
aspirational cut with a Godly touch and
essentially serves as a reminder of how
stormzy needed to persevere in order to
get to where he is today and also what
he's doing to maintain his spot in the
Limelight the next track on the record
features a beautiful musical passage on
pianos and vocals from samha it may take
up just a few minutes on the lp but it
still pick me up and then from here we
move into a somewhat weak final leg
there's Holy Spirit which is another
come to Jesus moment on the album
focusing on burdens trials and
tribulations personal flaws deserving
God's grace and love there's a lot of
group vocals and strings and pianos on
this cut but the sound and aesthetic of
the song overall is so obnoxiously
squeaky clean almost to the point where
it sounds artificial essentially
preventing the song from hitting the
spiritual highs that it's going for the
only track that really hit for me on the
back end of this LP was I got my smile
back which is a very powerful cut about
stormzy making his own way in life and
in the music industry while also
battling a variety of different mental
health demons that he talks about with
specificity on the back end of the track
with some very moving parting words if
there's one thing about this album that
I respect overall it's stormzy's writing
and his topical focus on things like
growth God being in love falling out of
love the symbolism of the fire of the
water plus it seems like he's in a very
good place emotionally and mentally on
this record too reaching a plane of
Serenity of some sort but this new
chapter for storm seems to have birthed
a lot of musically Bland and under
overwhelming moments on this LP so many
of these tracks are built on this kind
of over budget sentimentality that
reminds me of albums like Eminem's
Recovery for example which yes come from
a place of real personal struggle but
simultaneously uh sound like a really
bad movie that's trying to pull at your
heartstrings in the most obviously
desperate way so to be clear this record
isn't disappointing because it's happy
or positive or emotional or heartwarming
I just think these Vibes and themes
would have come across a lot better if
they were complimented with some more
distinct and organic instrumentation
because this album overall sounds like
stormzy had just a boat full of emotions
to get off his chest but then he just
handed them over to this focus group of
the most chart friendly producers and
writers that the industry could find and
now we have a record that yes feels
personal narratively but feels so
impersonal sonically I'm feeling a
strong five to a light 6 on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should I review

Subscribe and please don't cry hit the
Bell as well over here next to my head
is another video you can check out hit
that up or the link to subscribe to the
channel Anthony fantana stormzy the
